text: Chemotaxis requires a mechanism for the rotary flagella to propel the cell toward attractants or away from repellents.
When the cell veers away from the attractant, receptors send a signal that allows one the twist of the helix.
This switch in the direction of rotation disrupts the bundle of flagella, causing the cell to tumble briefly and end up pointed in a random direction.
The signal transduction mechanism is explained in Chapter 10.
The resulting pattern of movement generates a “biased random walk” in which How do bacteria connect their flagellar switching mechanism to the signal reception of their chemoreceptors?
The cell then swims off in the new direction.
When a cell is swimming toward an attractant chemical, the swim smoothly for a long stretch.
